page.title: 02Farming in Ythanwells.
page.content: At Ythanwells most of the people are farmers. Their farms are big enough to provide work for the farmer and his wife, but not to employ farmworkers. Most of the ground is arable, but on the higher ground there is some permanent grazing.Most of the farmers have Massey Ferguson or International tractors. They keep Hereford-Friesian crossed cows mated to a Charolais bull to provide beef cattle.Each farmer has twenty to thirty cattle.The sheep kept are mostly black- or greyface ewes, some crossed with Suffolk or Cheviot rams.On each farm the farmer grows turnips, barley, oats and grass for hay, which is baled with a round or square baler. Most farmers cut their silage and cart it into the silage pits, but now some wilted grass is baled and put in black polythene bags.
